top_comment.text:
*I. S. S.: A Song That's Really Out of This World!*

From the band that brought us the theme to *The Big Bang Theory*  comes 
another *art mets science first* in collaboration with +Canada's own +Chris 
Hadfield orbiting 240 miles above Earth in the ISS:   *the first single 
ever recorded between space and Earth.*  

+Chris Hadfield has been sharing his experiences aboard the ISS via twitter 
and G+ (thanks to his son, +Evan Hadfield for helping with that). In the 
video below he takes that up a notch: playing and singing along with The 
Barenaked Ladies and the Wexford Gleeks (Canada's reigning show choir 
champions).

Take a listen to *I. S. S.  (Is Somebody Singing),*  and you're guaranteed 
to get chills thinking about how far we've come, and how far we can go 
using science to advance man- and woman-kind.

And the next first from the ISS is coming up soon: *tune into **+NASA**'s 
first ever live HangOut from space on February 22, **10:30**-**11:30** ET,* 
 featuring astronauts +Chris Hadfield , Kevin Ford, and Tom Marshburn. More 
on that here: http://goo.gl/sCPm0

Thanks to the CBC ( +CBC News )  and the +Canadian Space Agency  for 
commissioning the song, along with the Coalition for Music Education.  


#ScienceSunday  ﻿
top_comment.author: Allison Sekuler

comments.text:
+rob M. I absolutely *love* Jean Michel Jarre and had no idea he was in 
discussions to do an earth-space concert years ago.  But it totally makes 
sense to me, it's his genre, his style, and he is an incredibly pioneering 
artist who takes risks and chances and I could definitely see him involved 
in something like this.  First, last, I wouldn't have cared where it fit 
into history, it just would have been an epic performance.  I still wish I 
could have seen his 12 Dreams of the Sun concert at the base of the 
Pyramids of Giza for the turn of the Millenium.    

All that said, Chris Hadfield is an inspiration and a legend.  
A true gift to the Universe.

Thank you Chris, for everything you've done.

You do it with separate signals. One feeds another and so on, the last one 
feeds the live feed. That works for the typical hangout, but Player 1 does

top_comment.text:
Music that is Out of This World

+Chris Hadfield is full of firsts - he's doing his first Ask Me Anything on Reddit from the ISS in a few hours (http://goo.gl/E5Sbs), he's doing a Google+ HangOut Live on Feb 22 with his astronaut colleagues, he first brought a collapsable guitar onto the Mir in his first space mission back in 1995 (http://goo.gl/sW5Ol), and now he's recording the first album from space. Here's one of the singles he just released in collaboration with the Barenaked Ladies and the Gleeks.

The history of playing musical instruments in space is, of course, much older. Thanks to +Peter Lindelauf for tracking this classic down: The Song from Outer Space  -- the crew of Gemini 6 spotted an object in a "polar orbit...traveling North to South" and played an appropriately themed song on a harmonica they'd smuggled into their spaceship.

#ScienceSunday   #scisunABS

comments.text:
I also wonder at the latency.  It does an orbit every 92 minutes. So, if 
the ISS is overhead, it could be within 300 to 600km of the earth for 
around 10 minutes... at 600km, that's a speed of light delay of 2ms.
So, if one assumes a direct link, it could be easy to sync up. I doubt 
Chris was seeing the folks on stage, so I wonder how the video link up 
works, but if it's one way, not a big deal...

comments.text:
+emily thibert  To record with this sound quality together with other 
singers you need: 1) a microphone close to the singer's mouth and 2) an ear 
phone so that he/she can co-ordinate with what others are singing - Ed 
Robertson has both, Chris Hadfield has neither.  There is a lot of 
background noise on the ISS so it is even more necessary than usual to have 
the microphone close to the singer's mouth.  To mime to pre-recorded sound 
takes only a loudspeaker.  There are two "grey things" which are always in 
pictures of the Cupola - I suspect they are head cusions for the operator 
of the robotic arm.

comments.text:
This is brilliant! I wonder how they managed the round-trip time, though. 
When I've called somebody on the other side of the planet in the past 
there's always been a significant delay. The limitation of the speed of 
light is going to be at least 0.13 seconds on its own (travelling shortest 
distance round the circumference of the earth), and I suspect signalling 
overhead would be substantially more than that. Manageable for a phone 
call, but how would you make music like that?

Theories:
1. My sums/guesses about signalling delay are wrong.
2. It turns out that a 0.3 second delay isn't noticeable.
3. They had to film this in a short window while the ISS was in range of a 
Canadian ground station.
4. It was prerecorded.

Any ideas?

top_comment.text:
*I. S. S.: A Song That's Really Out of This World!*

From the band that brought us the theme to *The Big Bang Theory*  comes 
another *art mets science first* in collaboration with +Canada's own +Chris 
Hadfield orbiting 240 miles above Earth in the ISS:   *the first single 
ever recorded between space and Earth.*  

+Chris Hadfield has been sharing his experiences aboard the ISS via twitter 
and G+ (thanks to his son, +Evan Hadfield for helping with that). In the 
video below he takes that up a notch: playing and singing along with The 
Barenaked Ladies and the Wexford Gleeks (Canada's reigning show choir 
champions).

Take a listen to *I. S. S.  (Is Somebody Singing),*  and you're guaranteed 
to get chills thinking about how far we've come, and how far we can go 
using science to advance man- and woman-kind.

And the next first from the ISS is coming up soon: *tune into **+NASA**'s 
first ever live HangOut from space on February 22, **10:30**-**11:30** ET,* 
 featuring astronauts +Chris Hadfield , Kevin Ford, and Tom Marshburn. More 
on that here: http://goo.gl/sCPm0

Thanks to the CBC ( +CBC News )  and the +Canadian Space Agency  for 
commissioning the song, along with the Coalition for Music Education.  


#ScienceSunday  ﻿

captions.text:
Chris: Welcome to the cupola, 
ready to play a little music!

Ed: Indeed! Your scenery looks 
a little nicer than ours!
Have you got everything you need?

Do you have your trusty 
floating guitar pick with you?

Excellent. 
Mine is subject to gravity.

Yeah, I know, 
yours matches your mission patch.

Gleeks, 
are you guys ready to do this?
Gleeks: Yeah!!
Ed: Chris? Ready to go?
Chris: Yes Ed, I'm ready.
Ed: Okay!
Chris: Let's do this!
Ed: Let's do it.
♫ folk-pop music ♫

Ed (singing): 
On solid fuel and wires

Turn the key 
and the light the fires.
We’re leaving Earth today
This rocket's burning bright,
We’ll soon be out of sight,
And orbiting in space.

Ed and Chris: 
Pushed back in my seat,
Look out my window.
There goes home.
That ball of shiny blue

houses everybody 
anybody ever knew.

All together: 
So sing your song, I’m listening
Out where stars are glistening

I can hear your voices 
bouncing off the moon
If you could see our nation

from the 
International Space Station

You’d know why 
I want to get back soon.
Gleeks: Get back soon...

Chris: 
Eighteen thousand miles an hour
Fueled by science and solar power
The oceans racing past...
At half a thousand tons
Ninety minutes moon to sun
A bullet can’t go half this fast

Ed and Chris: 
Floating from my seat
Look out my window
There goes home

Gleeks: 
There goes home...

Ed and Chris: 
That brilliant ball of blue

All together: Is where I’m from, 
and also where I’m going to...
So sing your song, I’m listening
Out where stars are glistening

I can hear your voices 
bouncing  off the moon
If you could see our Nation

from the 
International Space Station

Chris: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Get back soon...

Ed: All back and white 
just fades to grey

Where the sun rises 
sixteen times a day

Chris: You can’t make out borders 
from up here

Just a spinning ball 
within a tiny atmosphere
Gleeks: Atmosphere...

Ed and Chris: 
Pushed back in my seat
Look out my window
Here comes home
Gleeks: Ho-oooh-home....

Ed and Chris: 
What once  was fueled by fear

All together: Now has fifteen nations 
orbiting together here.
So sing your song, I’m listening
Out where stars are glistening

I can hear your voices 
bouncing off the moon
If you could see our nation

from the 
International Space Station

You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Get back soon...

Ed: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Getting back to you

Chris: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Getting back to you

Ed: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Getting back to you

Chris: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
